sources.name: Gemini Deep Research - Apple Mac Capabilities
Gemini Deep Research - Mac Optimization, Gaming, and History

entries.fact: Typical FPS scaling from 1080p baseline: 1440p ~70-75%, 4K ~35-45%
entries.details: GPU-bound games show more dramatic scaling; CPU-bound games less affected

entries.fact: M3 Pro at 1440p medium-high settings: 45-70 FPS in modern AAA titles
MacBook thermal throttling typically reduces performance 15-30% from peak
entries.details: Sustained workloads on MacBook Air see larger drops (30-40%) vs MacBook Pro (15-20%)

entries.fact: Rosetta 2 translation typically adds 10-20% overhead for x86 games
entries.details: First launch compiles translation cache; subsequent launches faster

entries.fact: 16GB unified memory handles most games at medium-high settings without texture swapping
entries.details: Some AAA titles with ultra textures may exceed 16GB VRAM-equivalent requirements

entries.fact: Shadow quality Ultra→High typically saves 10-15% GPU load with minimal visual impact
VSync adds 1-3 frames of input latency (16-50ms at 60Hz)
entries.details: Consider frame limiters as alternative for reduced tearing without full VSync latency

entries.fact: M4 Max achieves ~4,025 Geekbench 6 single-core score (Mac Studio) / ~3,915 (MacBook Pro)
entries.details: ~25% uplift over M3 Ultra and ~40% over M2 Ultra in single-core performance

entries.fact: M4 Max achieves ~25,600-25,650 Geekbench 6 multi-core score
entries.details: 16-core M4 Max is close to 32-core M3 Ultra (28,160) in multi-core due to N3E process efficiency

entries.fact: M4 base achieves ~3,750 single-core, ~14,500 multi-core, ~58,000 Metal GPU in Geekbench 6
MacBook Air M4 operates at peak 4.4 GHz for 0-2 minutes, throttles to ~3.0 GHz after 10+ minutes
entries.details: 0-2 min: Peak 4.4 GHz. 5 min: Heat soak, chassis reaches ~45°C. 10+ min: Performance stabilizes at ~75% of peak

entries.fact: MacBook Pro fans maintain CPU at ~85-90°C allowing sustained 4.0 GHz+ operation indefinitely
entries.details: Fans ramp to 4000-5000 RPM for thermal management

entries.fact: M4 Max scores ~1,800 in Cinebench 2024 GPU vs M2 Ultra's ~1,100
entries.details: M4 Max destroys M2 Ultra in rendering despite fewer cores due to hardware ray tracing. M2 calculates rays via software

entries.fact: M3 Max (48GB) achieves 78.35 FPS in Cyberpunk 2077 at 1080p without MetalFX
M3 Max (48GB) achieves 104.46 FPS in Cyberpunk 2077 at 1080p with MetalFX Quality
entries.details: MetalFX Quality mode provides +33% FPS improvement (78.35 to 104.46 FPS)

entries.fact: M4 Max cannot sustain 60 FPS at native 4K in Cyberpunk 2077 without aggressive MetalFX
entries.details: Achieves 30-40 FPS in dense urban environments without aggressive MetalFX intervention

entries.fact: Mac Mini M4 Pro achieves 126 FPS in Resident Evil Village at 1080p Max settings with MetalFX Quality
Mac Mini M4 Pro achieves 86 FPS in Resident Evil Village at 1440p Max settings with MetalFX Quality
M3 Max sustains 100-125 FPS in Valheim at 4K resolution through Rosetta 2 translation
entries.details: Demonstrates capability of Apple's translation engine. Users often run via Rosetta for mod compatibility

entries.fact: Grand Theft Auto V achieves 100+ FPS on M4 Pro via CrossOver
entries.details: DX11 title benefits from years of Wine/CrossOver optimization work

entries.fact: Nvidia Reflex can reduce system latency by up to 50% in GPU-bound scenarios
entries.details: Just-in-time rendering approach eliminates render queue latency. Most effective when GPU is bottleneck

entries.fact: Windows Game Mode impact is negligible on high-end CPUs (Ryzen 9, i9) but critical for stabilizing 1% lows on mid-range hardware
entries.details: High core count: background tasks rarely interfere. Mid-range: Game Mode critical for preventing background stealing cycles

entries.fact: Modern Nvidia GPUs (RTX 30/40 series) automatically lower clock speed when hitting thermal limit around 83C
entries.details: Causes performance inconsistency - makes undervolting preferable to overclocking for thermal margin
